headings.title: What are articles?
paragraphs: Articles are words put before other words to make those words mean something. Latin-based languages are really fond of this.
There are two main types of articles which you need to know about in german:

headings.title: Definite Articles
paragraphs: Der - Die - Das

headings.title: Indefinite Articles
paragraphs: Ein - Eine - Ein

headings.title: Grammatical Gender in German
paragraphs: Nouns in germans have genders. German has three genders in its grammar:
The above list doesn't represent the genders, but rather how the definite articles behave with each gender.

Noun gender is a linguistic category that may not necessarily reflect the biological or social association of a gender as a human might perceive it. A good example of this is the word "Das M√§dchen" (the girl) which might make sense to use Die instead of Das, but isn't because German do be like that sometimes.

Said differently, just because a noun is "feminine" or "masculine" to human norms, doesn't mean it's going to match the gender in german, although much of the time, it does (e.g. The Woman = Die Frau).

headings.title: Telling the difference
paragraphs: Although many methods exist out there to tell the gender of a word, they aren't 100% accurate, so realistically you'll have to memorize a lot of words and then rely on your gut to tell you the gender of any given word. This is something that happens after you've learned a sufficient number of words and you'll feel more confident in your guesses as time goes on.
Even native german speakers have trouble using the correct gender sometimes, so that should tell you something.
Regardless, there are a few methods that help with this. I recommend this video for that: How to know a word's gender | Super Easy German

headings.title: Gender and Articles
paragraphs: Definite and Indefinite articles change based on grammatical case and gender:

headings.title: Definite Articles Table
paragraphs: | Article | Nominative | Accusative | Dative | Genitive | | ------- | ---------- | ---------- | ------ | -------- | | Der     | Der        | Den        | Dem    | Des      | | Die     | Die        | Die        | Der    | Der      | | Das     | Das        | Das        | Dem    | Des      |

headings.title: Indefinite Articles Table
paragraphs: | Article | Nominative | Accusative | Dative | Genitive | | ------- | ---------- | ---------- | ------ | -------- | | Ein     | Ein        | Einen      | Einem  | Eines    | | Eine    | Eine       | Eine       | Einer  | Einer    | | Ein (N) | Ein        | Ein        | Einem  | Eines    |

headings.title: Determining Your Level
paragraphs: Knowing your level in German is the first step to knowing what to focus on next.

headings.title: Using the Search
paragraphs: The search feature enables you to find any resource on the website with ease, including the context and page which it can be found on.
In the future, you will also be able to see your recent searches as well as favorite searches which you access frequently.

headings.title: Roadmap
paragraphs: While this site is meant as a general reference which anyone can use at any time, there are some concepts that are more useful when you're starting out in learning German.

headings.title: Brace Yourself
paragraphs: Assuming your main language is English, you'll gain the most value from learning the differences between English and German as well as the similarities.
Here are the top offenders:

headings.title: The Standard Alphabet
paragraphs: The Alphabet in German is very similar to its English counterpart, with a few exceptions to how letters are pronounced and a few extra letters.

It's highly recommended that you listen to it being pronounced to get a better grasp. If you have trouble pronouncing a letter then it's not the end of the world and you shouldn't stress about it too much. You will pick it up with time as you learn more vocabulary and start having conversations.
This video can help with learning the pronounciation of many letters
You have your usual A -> Z (pronounciation links included for each):
Notable differences in letter names (compared to English) are:

headings.title: Special Letters
paragraphs: The German language has 3 special letters called Umlaute:
The two-dot symbol (¬®) on top of the previous letters is called an umlaut, hence the name.
There is also another well-known special letter called the eszett or scharfes S (Sharp S):
An interesting thing to know about this letter is that there are no words that start with it.

headings.title: A different method of writing special letters
paragraphs: Understandably, you may find yourself ignoring the Umlaute while starting out since they are not easy to write on a US Qwery layout keyboard. Nevertheless, you should be aware that changing an umlaut to a non-umlaut in a word could change its meaning completely.
In short: don't simply convert an umlaut to a non-umlaut while writing a word as that could change the meaning of the word entirely.
Luckily, there is a compromise.

In German, if you can't type or write special characters like √§, √∂, √º, or √ü, there's a workaround. For the umlauted vowels, you can replace them with "ae," "oe," or "ue," known as "Umlaut Ersatz."
Similarly, the sharp S (√ü) can be swapped with "ss," called "Eszett Ersatz."
You can see examples here

paragraphs: Coming Soon!

headings.title: Definite Articles Grammatical Cases Table
paragraphs: | Pronoun      | Accusative | Dative | Genitive | | ------------ | ---------- | ------ | -------- | | der          | den        | dem    | des      | | die          | die        | der    | der      | | das          | das        | dem    | des      | | die (plural) | die        | den    | der      |

headings.title: Indefinite Articles Grammatical Cases Table
paragraphs: | Pronoun      | Accusative | Dative | Genitive | | ------------ | ---------- | ------ | -------- | | ein          | einen      | einem  | eines    | | eine         | eine       | einer  | einer    | | ein (neuter) | ein        | einem  | eines    |
Note: the same rules apply for other words that act like indefinite articles, including:

headings.title: Personal Pronouns Grammatical Cases Table
paragraphs: | Pronoun    | Accusative | Dative | | ---------- | ---------- | ------ | | ich        | mich       | mir    | | du         | dich       | dir    | | er         | ihn        | ihm    | | sie        | sie        | ihr    | | es         | es         | ihm    | | wir        | uns        | uns    | | ihr        | euch       | euch   | | sie (they) | sie        | ihnen  | | Sie (You)  | Sie        | Ihnen  |

headings.title: The Accusative
paragraphs: The accusative in german means when you're targeting something in your verb, not as the recipient of an action but more so as the affected entity.
Accusative causes articles to change into different forms.
Example:

headings.title: Table of Personal Pronouns with the Accusative
paragraphs: | Pronoun   | Accusative | | --------- | ---------- | | ich       | mich       | | du        | dich       | | er        | ihn        | | sie       | sie        | | es        | es         | | wir       | uns        | | ihr       | euch       | | sie       | sie        | | Sie (You) | Sie        |

headings.title: Table of Possessive Pronouns with the Accusative
paragraphs: | Article | Nominative | Accusative | Dative | Genitive | | ------- | ---------- | ---------- | ------ | -------- | | Der     | Der        | Den        | Dem    | Des      | | Die     | Die        | Die        | Der    | Der      | | Das     | Das        | Das        | Dem    | Des      |

headings.title: Prepositions and Adverbs for Directions and Locations
paragraphs: | English         | German     | Case Example (Accusative for motion, Dative for position) | Example Sentence                                                                               | | --------------- | ---------- | --------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | in front of     | vor        | vor dem Haus (in front of the house)                      | Wir warten vor dem Kino. (We are waiting in front of the cinema.)                              | | next to         | neben      | neben dem Auto (next to the car)                          | Ich stehe neben dem Auto. (I stand next to the car.)                                           | | behind          | hinter     | hinter dem Geb√§ude (behind the building)                  | Das Fahrrad steht hinter dem Haus. (The bike is behind the house.)                             | | above           | √ºber       | √ºber dem Tisch (above the table)                          | Die Lampe h√§ngt √ºber dem Tisch. (The lamp hangs above the table.)                              | | below           | unter      | unter der Br√ºcke (below the bridge)                       | Das Boot f√§hrt unter der Br√ºcke. (The boat goes under the bridge.)                             | | on              | auf        | auf dem Tisch (on the table)                              | Das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch. (The book is on the table.)                                      | | between         | zwischen   | zwischen den St√ºhlen (between the chairs)                 | Die Katze sitzt zwischen den St√ºhlen. (The cat sits between the chairs.)                       | | inside          | in         | im Haus (inside the house)                                | Wir sind im Haus. (We are inside the house.)                                                   | | outside         | au√üerhalb  | au√üerhalb des Gartens (outside the garden)                | Sie warten au√üerhalb des Geb√§udes. (They are waiting outside the building.)                    | | to the right of | rechts von | rechts vom Baum (to the right of the tree)                | Der Parkplatz ist rechts vom Supermarkt. (The parking lot is to the right of the supermarket.) | | to the left of  | links von  | links vom Haus (to the left of the house)                 | Der Briefkasten ist links von der T√ºr. (The mailbox is to the left of the door.)               | | inside (adv)    | drinnen    | -                                                         | Wir sind drinnen. (We are inside.)                                                             | | outside (adv)   | drau√üen    | -                                                         | Die Kinder spielen drau√üen. (The children are playing outside.)                                |

headings.title: Cardinal Directions in German
paragraphs: | English | German | Definite Article | | ------- | ------ | ---------------- | | North   | Norden | der Norden       | | South   | S√ºden  | der S√ºden        | | East    | Osten  | der Osten        | | West    | Westen | der Westen       |

headings.title: Intermediate Directions in German
paragraphs: | English   | German     | Definite Article | | --------- | ---------- | ---------------- | | Northeast | Nordosten  | der Nordosten    | | Southeast | S√ºdosten   | der S√ºdosten     | | Southwest | S√ºdwesten  | der S√ºdwesten    | | Northwest | Nordwesten | der Nordwesten   |

headings.title: Shapes (Die Form - Die Formen)
paragraphs: The basic forms in german (die Grundformen) include the following:

| English Term  | German (Singular with Article) | Plural Form          | Adjective (Shape)             | | ------------- | ------------------------------ | -------------------- | ----------------------------- | | Circle        | Der Kreis                      | Die Kreise           | kreisf√∂rmig (circular)        | | Square        | Das Quadrat                    | Die Quadrate         | quadratisch (square)          | | Rectangle     | Das Rechteck                   | Die Rechtecke        | rechteckig (rectangular)      | | Triangle      | Das Dreieck                    | Die Dreiecke         | dreieckig (triangular)        | | Oval          | Das Oval                       | Die Ovale            | oval (oval)                   | | Diamond       | Die Raute                      | Die Rauten           | rautenf√∂rmig (diamond-shaped) | | Line          | Die Linie                      | Die Linien           | linear (linear)               | | Straight Line | Die Gerade Linie               | Die Geraden Linien   | gerade (straight)             | | Curved Line   | Die Gebogene Linie             | Die Gebogenen Linien | gebogen (curved)              | | Dot           | Der Punkt                      | Die Punkte           | punktf√∂rmig (dot-like)        | | Polygon       | Das Polygon                    | Die Polygone         | polygonal (polygonal)         | | Cube          | Der W√ºrfel                     | Die W√ºrfel           | w√ºrfelf√∂rmig (cubical)        | | Sphere        | Die Kugel                      | Die Kugeln           | kugelf√∂rmig (spherical)       | | Cylinder      | Der Zylinder                   | Die Zylinder         | zylinderf√∂rmig (cylindrical)  | | Cone          | Der Kegel                      | Die Kegel            | kegelf√∂rmig (conical)         | | Hexagon       | Das Sechseck                   | Die Sechsecke        | sechseckig (hexagonal)        | | Pentagon      | Das F√ºnfeck                    | Die F√ºnfecke         | f√ºnfeckig (pentagonal)        | | Star          | Der Stern                      | Die Sterne           | sternf√∂rmig (star-shaped)     |
